The `{ino}` R package provides tools for the analysis of the initialization for numerical optimization. For detailed examples and usage instructions, please refer to the [vignettes](https://loelschlaeger.de/ino/articles/) accompanying the package.

## Installation

You can install the released version from [CRAN](https://CRAN.R-project.org) with:

```{r, install released, eval = FALSE}
install.packages("ino")
```

And the development version from [GitHub](https://github.com/) with:

```{r, install dev, eval = FALSE}
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("loelschlaeger/ino")
```

## Example

The [Ackley function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackley_function) has multiple local minima and one global minimum in the origin. 

```{r, ackley function}
f_ackley <- function(x) {
  stopifnot(is.numeric(x), length(x) == 2)
  -20 * exp(-0.2 * sqrt(0.5 * (x[1]^2 + x[2]^2))) -
    exp(0.5 * (cos(2 * pi * x[1]) + cos(2 * pi * x[2]))) + exp(1) + 20
}
f_ackley(c(0, 0))
```

The optimization result depends on the initial value:

```{r, ackley demo, message = FALSE}
library("ino")
Nop$new(objective = f_ackley, npar = 2)$
  set_optimizer(optimizeR::optimizer_nlm())$
  initialize_random(runs = 100)$
  optimize()$
  optima(digits = 2)
```
